column4: I just installed nvidia drivers through automatix, and I appear to have nice, accelerated graphics, but now my screen resolution is stuck at 800x600.  I ran dpkg-reconfigure xserver-corg to reset my options (I had to do that in the first place, actually).  Even after reboot, I have no other options other than 800x600.  See my xorg.conf (http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/20164), seems like I should have 1280x1024 and 1024x768, too....
Is there another way to change the screen resolution?
my question's not really automatix related...but looking for another way to change screen resolution...
Ahh, then maybe only mepis
ok bluueeagle, i'll ask there
What in particular do you want to know about su?
ReWt_AxS k3b (in kde distros)
Maybe that user needs to be added to a group...
well, a group like sudo, etc. (I wouldn't be sure which one right off the top of my head)
sorry I have been out of the convo for a few minutes, but have you tried running /usr/bin/gnome-display-properties wrt changing screen rez?
try it sudo/gksudo if it fails as a plebe, on my boxes it runs fine as me
have a look in /etc/X11/xorg.conf and see what resolutions are listed under screen->display
it is easy to change that file, but you will have to be root, make you BACK IT UP first, and you will need to restart X for it to take effect (control-alt-backspace for the impatient)
in case somebody else didn't ask, does control-alt+plus, control-alt-minus do anything at all?
Didn't work...I've never heard of doing that before - is that a gnome trick?
control-alt-plus/minus to shift resolution is part of X itself, although it can be disabled.  It's from the same people that give you control-alt-backspace when you are parranoid
is the display in question an lcd panel that you wish to run at only it's native resolution?
still, you might just try making a backup of that file and then removing everything except "1280x1024" (if that is what you want)
I think I will give that a try
*then* try that control-alt-backsapce
I'm back, and I am still stuck in 800x600.  I noticed in my xorg.conf that Section "Device" shows " BusID                "PCI:3:0:0"" - is this correct, since my card is AGP?
